Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Paleobiogeography, paleoecology, and continued investigation of a diverse, terminal Miocene, primate-bearing fauna from southern China

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The early and middle Miocene (ca. 23-11 million years ago) witnessed an expansion of the world's tropical and subtropical forests, and an increase in the diversity and distribution of mammals that thrived in forests with low seasonality and high productivity. Apes flourished under these conditions in the Old World. The contraction of subtropical forests in the late Miocene in Eurasia resulted in a decline in the diversity and abundance of apes, and the rise of monkeys and other mammals able to survive in more open and seasonal habitats. Several fossil sites in southern China provide evidence of this critical transition. In this project, the fossil site of Shuitangba, Yunnan Province, China, will be investigated because it has yielded the abundant and well-preserved remains of many mammal species of terminal Miocene age (~6.1 mya). Among them are an ape and a monkey, the first such co-occurrence in the Miocene of Eurasia. Recovery and detailed study of the fossils by an international team of American and Chinese investigators will make possible the characterization of the paleoenvironment of Shuitangba and the nature and adaptations of the site's many species, especially its primates and carnivores. Direct comparison of the Shuitangba biota with others of similar age in eastern Asia will provide a clearer idea of the nature and pace of environmental evolution in the region.

Shuitangba captures a unique snapshot of the transition from the widespread evergreen forests of the Miocene to the more heterogeneous and seasonal habitats that followed. This project thus promotes the understanding of an ecosystem poised at the tipping point of a major change. The Shuitangba fauna and environment provide an unusually clear picture of a distinctive regional ecosystem that contained long-established species alongside new arrivals. A better understanding of the adaptations of species within such ecosystems may shed light on the dynamics of modern unstable environments.

This project fosters strong international collaboration with Chinese scholars, including advanced training for Chinese paleoanthropologists, paleobiologists, and fossil preparators, and promotes public science education in China through media coverage and development of museum displays. A junior US scientist will be integrally involved in the research, and US undergraduate students also will receive substantial participatory research training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results of this project shed new and significant light on the evolution of mammals during one of the most remarkable periods of terrestrial environmental change, the end of the Miocene Epoch. Focused on the lignite mine site of Shuitangba in the Zhaotong Basin at the southeastern edge of the Tibetan Plateau in Yunnan Province of southwestern China, the project yielded thousands of vertebrate fossils from the latest Miocene through the earliest Pliocene (about 7-5 million years ago). During this period, the Zhaotong Basin became filled by clays, silts, peaty clays, and lignites, which were deposited under lacustrine or swampy conditions. The Shuitangba site at this time supported a rich biota of water-birds, water-loving mammals (such as beaver and giant otter), water-loving insectivores, rodents, and rabbits, and two highly significant primates, an ape and a monkey. During our project, the richest fossil-bearing sediments at the site were securely dated by paleomagnetism at about 6.2 million years and were revealed to have been deposited over a relatively short period of geological time, probably only a few thousand years, in relatively still water. This remarkable preserving environment made it possible for even the most fragile bones of birds and small mammals to be preserved unusually well, thus facilitating their identification.

 

The vertebrate fossils retrieved from the Shuitangba site exceeded all expectations in their number, quality of preservation, taxonomic diversity, and overall significance. Bird fossils constituted the majority of the vertebrate fossil bones collected at Shuitangba, and the vast majority of these represented water birds. The four modern guilds of diving birds were present at the site, the only known terrestrial fossil site of any age with this distinction. The remarkable preservation of small mammals permitted reconstruction of the paleoenvironment to a high degree of fidelity because of the great habitat specificity of most of the species. The highly diverse assemblage of insectivores included an erinaceid “moon rat,” a large mole, and at least two shrews, all of which prefer moist habitats. Significant also was the first appearance of the modern “swamp rabbit,” now present only in isolated habitats of Laos, one of the world’s few water-loving rabbits. Bamboo rats were plentiful and diverse, and beavers constituted a large proportion of fossils retrieved, probably by virtue of their large size. The ecological situation revealed by the small mammal fauna was that of a dominant wetland, probably fringed by a slightly more open habitat. The other habitué of the shallow waters of Shuitangba revealed by our research was a new species of giant otter (illustrated below), which appears to have fed on the freshwater oysters that were common at the site. Small carnivores such as martens, civets, and one small bear were also recovered from the site. Two proboscideans (large elephants or elephant-like mammals) were also present at Shuitangba, both among the earliest representatives of their respective groups. These large mammals moved easily over landscapes and watercourses, so their presence at the site indicated only that they came there to drink. The mammals of greatest significance retrieved from the site were the primates. The ape recovered was a well-known late Miocene genus, represented by the nearly complete cranium of a juvenile individual that has been studied in detail. The monkey recovered was also a well-known late Miocene genus, but never before recovered from a site in eastern Asia and therefore of great significance.

 

The comprehensive study of the Shuitangba fauna and environment that was completed during this project revealed a snapshot of unprecedented clarity of late Miocene environments, just before major global environmental changes leading to the modern era. The research project so far has yielded six publications, and more – including a major environmental synthesis paper – are in preparation.
